articles.headline: Report Details How Madoff’s Web Ensnared S.E.C.
articles.snippet: Three agency examinations and two investigations of Bernard Madoff’s business were incompetent, according to a report by the S.E.C. inspector general.
articles.abstract: Three agency examinations and two investigations of Bernard Madoff’s business were incompetent, according to a report by the S.E.C. inspector general.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Unseasoned investigators from the Securities and Exchange Commission were alternately intimidated and enthralled by a name-dropping, yarn-spinning Bernard L. Madoff as he dodged questions about his financial house of cards, according to a scathing new report on the agency’s repeated failure to uncover the huge investment fraud.

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Great Scenes, Starring You
articles.snippet: Yoostar’s special-effects software puts you in the picture with your favorite movie stars. But the technology isn’t quite ready for its close-up.
articles.abstract: Yoostar’s special-effects software puts you in the picture with your favorite movie stars. But the technology isn’t quite ready for its close-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t believe how often greenscreen effects show up in movies these days. Heard of it? That’s where, while filming, the actors perform in front of a wall (or an entire set) that’s been painted solid bright green. Only in their heads do they see outer space, or ancient Rome, or the Matrix. Later, software replaces every speck of green in that footage with preselected background video. The result: The actors look as if they’ve been in the Matrix all along.

articles.headline: YouTube May Offer Pay Movies
articles.snippet: The video site is said to be in talks with Hollywood studios over an agreement that would allow it to stream movies to users for a fee.
articles.abstract: The video site is said to be in talks with Hollywood studios over an agreement that would allow it to stream movies to users for a fee.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube, the largest video site, is in negotiations with major Hollywood studios for a deal that would let its visitors pay to watch full-length movies, according to two people briefed on the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: In Bank Killings, Highs and Lows of Iraq Justice
articles.snippet: A bank robbery has resonated for what it says about Iraq’s corruption and the uneven application of law.
articles.abstract: A bank robbery has resonated for what it says about Iraq’s corruption and the uneven application of law.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The gang of robbers did not have to worry about the police because, in that neighborhood, they were the police, many of them bodyguards for one of the nation’s most powerful men, Vice President Adel Abdul Mahdi.
articles.byline: By Rod Nordland and Riyadh Mohammed

articles.headline: Customers Angered as iPhones Overload AT&T
articles.snippet: The cellular network is straining to meet iPhone users’ demand, resulting in dropped calls and delayed messages.
articles.abstract: The cellular network is straining to meet iPhone users’ demand, resulting in dropped calls and delayed messages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Slim and sleek as it is, the iPhone is really the Hummer of cellphones.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Support May Be Vital to Obama on Afghan War
articles.snippet: Congressional Democrats are reporting disenchantment among constituents with a long Afghanistan conflict, but national security hawks still back the president.
articles.abstract: Congressional Democrats are reporting disenchantment among constituents with a long Afghanistan conflict, but national security hawks still back the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to decide whether to send additional troops to Afghanistan, the political climate appears increasingly challenging for him, leaving him in the awkward position of relying on the Republican Party, and not his own, for support.

articles.headline: At ABC, an Anchor Shift; for TV, an Image Shift
articles.snippet: Diane Sawyer’s arrival at ABC’s “World News” will alter the image of an avuncular male nightly news anchor.
articles.abstract: Diane Sawyer’s arrival at ABC’s “World News” will alter the image of an avuncular male nightly news anchor.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Diane Sawyer was on stage with Whitney Houston before a crowd in Central Park. On Wednesday, she was crowned the leader of ABC’s network news division.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: White House to Propose Big Reserves at Banks
articles.snippet: Bankers oppose a buildup in capital cushions because it reduces the amount of money available for investing, and therefore eats into profits.
articles.abstract: Bankers oppose a buildup in capital cushions because it reduces the amount of money available for investing, and therefore eats into profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many banks are finally back on their feet. The question now is how to keep them there for good.

articles.headline: High Stakes for Merck in Litigation on Fosamax
articles.snippet: Merck spent $7 million in the second quarter to defend itself in the first of at least 900 pending cases in which plaintiffs claim that taking Fosamax caused jaw injuries.
articles.abstract: Merck spent $7 million in the second quarter to defend itself in the first of at least 900 pending cases in which plaintiffs claim that taking Fosamax caused jaw injuries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Drug executives, product liability lawyers and Wall Street analysts are closely watching a jury trial in New York over medical problems associated with Fosamax, a drug from Merck that has been taken by millions of women to offset the bone loss associated with menopause.

articles.headline: Kennedy Memoir Doesn’t Ignore Lows
articles.snippet: In a book being published this month, Edward M. Kennedy does not shy from some unsavory aspects of his life.
articles.abstract: In a book being published this month, Edward M. Kennedy does not shy from some unsavory aspects of his life.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a memoir being published this month, Senator Edward M. Kennedy called his behavior after the 1969 car accident that killed Mary Jo Kopechne “inexcusable” and said the events might have shortened the life of his ailing father, Joseph P. Kennedy.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and John M. Broder

articles.headline: A Reluctance to Retire Means Fewer Openings
articles.snippet: Potential retirees in the U.S. are clinging to jobs because of financial losses, while Europeans are retiring in lockstep.
articles.abstract: Potential retirees in the U.S. are clinging to jobs because of financial losses, while Europeans are retiring in lockstep.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the long list of reasons American companies aren’t hiring  business losses, tight credit, consumer retrenchment  add the fact that many of their older workers are unable, or afraid, to retire.
articles.byline: By Catherine Rampell and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Editor Resigns Over Berlusconi-Tied Accusations
articles.snippet: The editor of a Catholic newspaper in Italy stepped down days after a paper tied to Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi accused him of being a homosexual.
articles.abstract: The editor of a Catholic newspaper in Italy stepped down days after a paper tied to Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi accused him of being a homosexual.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  For months, the staid newspaper of the Italian Bishops’ Conference,  Avvenire, steered largely clear of the major topic of conversation here: the spicy personal life of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.
